questionText: A 10 year old child has undergone surgery and has been received in to the ward with severe pains. Which immediate post-operative pain relief medication would be effective for this child?
rationale: It is a potent opioid analgesic that is effective in treating severe pain in post-operative patients.

questionText: A 12-year old Master Setor has been admitted to your ward with the diagnosis of tonsillitis. Which of the following manifestation of patient indicates a systemic response of inflammatory process of his conditions?
rationale: Because it is a physiological response triggered by the release of cytokines which initiates an inflammatory process, a sign of the body's immune system trying to fight off an infection or inflammation.

questionText: A 15 year old boy was sent to the medical ward with history of poor quality of life since birth. After series of investigation there was a final diagnosis of congenital megacolon. Possible diagnostic investigation requested for patient could be:
rationale: Barium enema is the most appropriate investigation for diagnosing congenital megacolon as it allows direct visualization of the dilated colon.

questionText: A 16 year old boy has been booked for laparotomy following a diagnosis of intestinal obstruction. Describe the measures for allaying his anxiety prior to surgery? I. Allow patient to express his fears and anxiety II. Encourage patient to start grieving before the surgery III. Ensure relative stay with patient 24 hours
rationale: Encouraging the patient to start grieving before the surgery may increase his stress levels, while ensuring a relative stays with the patient for 24 hours may not be feasible and to necessarily alleviate the patient's anxiety.

questionText: A 17-year-old student has been booked for laparotomy following a diagnosis of intestinal obstruction. Which of the following measures would you put in place to allay patient's anxiety prior to the surgery? I. Allow patient to express fears and anxieties II. Encourage patient to start grieving before the surgery III. Ensure relatives stay with patient 24 hours IV. Provide a relaxed and non-threatening atmosphere.
rationale: Encouraging the patient to start grieving before the surgery may increase his anxiety and stress levels, while ensuring a relative stays with the patient for 24 hours may not be feasible and may not necessarily alleviate the patient's anxiety.

questionText: A 19-year-old female complains of a tender fluctuating left subareolar breast mass. The patient states that she noticed the mass at or around 4 months after giving birth. She denies fever, discomfort, skin changes, trauma to the breast or change in diet. She denies taking any medications and does not breastfeed. Physical exam reveals a slightly larger left breast as compared to the right. No skin changes are noted but a mass is palpable. A white transparent fluid is exuded from bilateral nipples. Ultrasound-guided aspiration of the mass is performed and reveals an echogenic cystic structure with a milk-like fluid. Fat globules are appreciated from the aspirated cyst contents. What is the next best step in management for this patient?
options: Excisional biopsy with wide margins of the cyst.
Initiate a short course of bromocriptine.
Follow-up ultrasound to ensure cyst has not recurred.
rationale: This will ensure that the cyst has resolved on its own and has not recurred. Option A is incorrect since the ultrasound-guided aspiration did not reveal malignancy, and Bromocriptine is not indicated since there is no evidence of a hormone-related disorder.

questionText: A 19-year-old female who bites her nails presents with pain that she relates to a hangnail. On examination, there is a painful, fluctuant area with erythema at the proximal nail bed. She has full painless range of motion of the joints of her finger. Sensation is intact. What is the patient's diagnosis?
rationale: Paronychia is a common infection of the nail fold that can be caused by bacteria, fungi or viruses, and it typically presents as a painful, red, swollen, and tender area around the nail, which may contain pus or fluid, and in severe cases, it may lead to the formation of an abscess or cellulitis.

questionText: A 20 year old level 100 student was brought to the OPD by her roommate with complains of inability to sleep and concentrate in class. During history taking, Patient told you she will start menstruation in the next 2 days. She added that she usually feel this way before menstruation. What will be the possible diagnosis of her problem?
rationale: PMDD is a condition in which a woman experiences severe emotional and physical symptoms, such as irritability, mood swings, depression, and bloating, in the days leading up to her menstrual period.

questionText: A 20-year-old dispatch rider was rushed to the emergency unit with difficulty in breathing. restlessness, chest pain, lacerations on the face and a lost tooth in a fight with a colleague rider. Upon assessment he was diagnosed with Pneumothorax. Which position would ensure improvement in respiration rate? position.
rationale: Pneumothorax is a condition in which air accumulates in the pleural space, causing the lung to collapse and leading to difficulty in breathing. Fowler's position helps to improve respiration by expanding the chest and reducing pressure on the diaphragm.

questionText: A 21-year-old SIIS graduate reported to your facility with the complaints of swollen neck. On assessment she was diagnosed of having a simple goitre. Which of the following signs and symptoms upon assessment indicate the patient would need a surgical treatment? I. Dysphagia. II. Dyspnea. III. Hoarseness of voice. IV. Cosmetic disfigurement.
rationale: Dysphagia can cause difficulty in swallowing, dyspnoea can cause difficulty in breathing, hoarseness of voice can cause difficulties in speech, and cosmetic disfigurement can affect the patient's self-esteem and quality of life. All these are significant signs and symptoms that indicate the need for surgical intervention to relieve symptoms and prevent further complications.

questionText: A 23 year old lady with a 3 day old new born baby noticed that the baby had not passed stools since birth. She took the baby to the Traditional Birth Attendant who examined the baby and realized that the baby had no anus. The mother and her baby have been referred to your facility for emergency surgery to correct the anomaly. Which operation is likely to be performed for the baby?
rationale: It involves creating a new anal opening and reconstructing the rectum to allow for normal bowel movements.

questionText: A 23 year old patient is admitted to the surgical ward on account of suspected appendicitis. The patient complains of pain around the umbilicus that extends to the lower part of the abdomen, which is about one third distance between the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus. Patient's pain is likely to be emanating from...... point.
rationale: Is a classic sign of appendicitis due to its location at the intersection of the right lateral abdominal muscles and the line drawn from the right anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus, where tenderness is often present during inflammation of the appendix.

questionText: A 23 year old patient is admitted to the surgical ward on account of suspected appendicitis. The patient complains of pain around the umbilicus that extends to the lower part of the abdomen, which is about one third distance between the anterior superior illiac spine and umbilicus. Which of the following is NOT a clinical manifestation of appendicitis?
options: Umbilical pain that extends in the right lower quadrant.
rationale: Inflamed appendices cause abdominal rigidity, not flaccidity.

questionText: A 23-year-old female with a history of smoking is on admission on your ward for the removal of uterine fibroids. Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for postoperative nausea and vomiting?
rationale: Being a female is not a risk factor in and of itself.

questionText: A 24-year old woman comes into your office after spilling hot tea on her hand. The affected area is red with a few blisters. On examination, the burn blanched with pressure. The patient notes worsening pain when the burn is exposed to the cold wind. How would you classify this burn?
rationale: The presence of redness, blisters, and pain are indicative of a burn affecting the epidermis and upper dermis. The blanching with pressure also suggests that the burn has not destroyed the underlying dermal vessels.

questionText: A 25-year old man undergoes 3 column excisional hemorrhoidectomy for combined internal external hemorrhoids unresponsive to medical therapy. Later that evening of the postoperative day zero, he develops suprapubic discomfort and inability to urinate. Which of the following likely contributed the MOST to this complication?
options: Limiting intravenous fluids in the postoperative recovery unit.
rationale: This may have caused the compression of the pudendal nerve which plays a role in controlling the external urethral sphincter, leading to urinary retention and suprapubic discomfort.

questionText: A 25-year-old university student reports at your facility with a small painless lump in her left breast. She is anxious that it might be cancer because her mother died of cervical cancer. Your response to her will be based on the knowledge that the MOST likely cause of breast lump is
rationale: Fibroadenomas are the most common type of benign breast tumour and are frequently seen in young women. Breast abscess and fibrocystic complex are less likely causes of a painless breast lump in a young woman.

questionText: A 25-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Unit with burns sustained after dropping a pan of hot oil. The Nurse noticed bright red skin with bullae on the anterior trunk and the right arm. The patient states her pain is 9 on a scale of 1-10. What is the total body surface area (TBSA) of the patient's burns?
rationale: According to the rule of nines, the anterior trunk represents 18% of the total body surface area, while the right arm represents 9% of the total body surface area. Therefore, the total body surface area (TBSA) of the patient's burns would be 18% + 9% = 27%.

questionText: A 27-year-old Mechanic with burns is to be admitted to your ward where you work. Upon assessment, you noticed that he has fluid filled vesicles that are red, shiny and moderate oedema on the face, anterior trunk, and in both arms and legs. He is also in severe pains suspected to be caused by nerve injury. Which of the following actions would you avoid in order to prevent infection of patient's wound?
options: Adhering to strict hand hygiene practices in the care of the patient.
Covering patient's wound with prescribed antimicrobial cream.
Using a clean glove when applying antimicrobial ointments.
rationale: Covering the patient's wound with antimicrobial cream may trap in moisture and create a favourable environment for bacterial growth, leading to wound infection.

questionText: A 27-year-old Seamstress is to be admitted to your ward for further management of burns involving the face, anterior trunk, arms, perineum and both legs. She was unconscious on arrival. Which of the following complications of the urinary system is the patient likely to experience in the emergent phase?
rationale: Due to the decrease in renal blood flow, caused by hypovolemia and/or hypotension, which can result in acute tubular necrosis and subsequent renal failure.

questionText: A 29-year-old Teacher with a diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus reported with a necrossed wound on the right limb which had spread to adjacent tissues. The Surgeon recommended below knee amputation which was subsequently done. Later, patient complained she felt the limb was still present. Which of the following post-operative nursing diagnosis would be considered when caring for the patient? Surgical Nursing I. Disturbed body image related to amputation. II. Impaired physical mobility related to amputation of lower limb. III. Ineffective airway clearance related to bronchial obstruction.
rationale: Option III is not relevant to the patient's situation as it does not address any issues related to the amputation of the patient's limb.

questionText: A 30-year old lady went through a routine assessment of the cervical epithelium. The histology report revealed changes in cell size, shape and organization. This indicates cellular ......
rationale: Cellular dysplasia refers to abnormal changes in the size, shape and organization of cells which can potentially lead to cancer formation if left untreated.

questionText: A 30-year-old dispatch rider was rushed to the emergency unit with difficulty in breathing, restlessness, chest pain, lacerations on the face and a lost tooth in a fight with a colleague rider. Upon assessment he was diagnosed with Pneumothorax. A chest tube has been inserted for a patient with pneumothorax. Which of the following is an appropriate finding when assessing the chest tube drainage system?
options: Accumulation of clots in the tubing.
Chest tube is inserted in the fifth intercostal space.
rationale: It indicates that air is being removed from the pleural space through the chest tube, which is necessary for the lungs to re-expand and for the pneumothorax to resolve.

questionText: A 30-year-old female is diagnosed with Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. Which of the following characterizes this disorder?
rationale: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is autoimmune disorder in which the body produces antibodies against its own thyroid gland, leading to inflammation and damage to the gland, which results in decreased production of thyroid hormones (hypothyroidism).

questionText: A 30-year-old female undergoes CT scan for a minor trauma and is found incidentally to have a 2cm cystic mass in the presacral space. She is otherwise health, with no family history. Reetal exam confirms a small mass felt posteriority. The examining finger is able to easily reach above the mass. MRI confirms a cystic lesion without invasion. What do you recommend next?
rationale: The patient is asymptomatic and the lesion is incidentally discovered. The fact that the examining finger can easily reach above the mass suggests that it is low in the presacral space, making malignancy less likely. Additionally, the MRI confirms a cystic lesion without invasion. Therefore, observation is the most appropriate next step.

questionText: A 30-year-old male patient complains of diffuse low back pain without radicular symptom. His pain is worse in the morning and usually improves with ibuprofen. Radiographic studies reveal a "bamboo" appearance to the spine. Which of the following is most likely the cause of the patient's back pain?
rationale: The "bamboo" appearance of the spine on radiographic studies is a classic finding of ankylosing spondylitis, a chronic inflammatory disease that affects the spine and sacroiliac joints.

questionText: A 30-year-old Microsoft Developer reported to the Out Patient Department of your hospital with a history of blurred vision as a result of splash of pepper in the right eye. At the hospital, he was taken through a series of visual test and examinations. A diagnosis of glaucoma was finally made. Which of the following are possible nursing diagnosis for the patient.
rationale: I and III can increase the risk of injury and affect the patient's ability to perform activities of daily living, while II is not relevant as glaucoma does not directly affect fluid volume.

questionText: A 30-year-old reported to the Out Patient Department of your hospital with a history of blurred vision as a result of splash of pepper in the right eye. At the hospital, she was taken through series of visual test and examination. A diagnosis of glaucoma was finally made. Visual acuity of the patient can be measured using a Snellen's chart placed at ...... m from the patient
rationale: To provide a standardized distance for measuring visual acuity, which is determined by the smallest letters that a person can read accurately from that distance.

questionText: A 32 year old known hypertensive is admitted to your ward for abdominal surgery. During your assessment, you found out that he uses diuretics to manage the hypertension. Which of the following would you reports to the surgeon?
options: Pulse rate of 105 beats per minutes
rationale: Diuretics can cause potassium loss through increased urine output, and low serum potassium levels can result in life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.

questionText: A 32 year old Mason has been referred to your facility with the diagnosis of spinal injury secondly to fall from height two days ago. On arrival to your ward, you noticed that patient was dehydrated and his rounds, patient's doctor said the healthcare team should immobilize patient's neck. As a Nurse, which of the following techniques would you avoid in stabilizing the patients neck? The use of a
rationale: The use of a backrest can cause hyperextension of the neck and further damage to the spinal cord, making it an inappropriate technique for stabilizing the patient's neck.

questionText: A 32 year old woman has been admitted for knee surgery. Which of the following data obtained from her during your pre-operative assessment should be reported to the surgeon before surgery?
options: Lack of knowledge of the procedure.
History of postoperative infection following a enesarean section.
Statement that her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago,
rationale: This could indicate a risk for surgical site infection during the knee surgery. The surgeon may want to take additional precautions or prescribe prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infection. Option C is important to note for anaesthetists but not necessarily for the surgeon,

questionText: A 32-year-old food vendor is to be admitted to your ward for further management of burns involving the face, anterior trunk, arms, perineum and both legs. She was unconscious on arrival. The cardiovascular system complications that the patient is most likely to experience are dysrhythmia and ....... shock.
rationale: Burns involving a large surface area of the body can lead to a significant loss of fluids and electrolytes, resulting in hypovolemia and subsequent shock.

questionText: A 33 year old banker reports to your facility with complains of low appetite and fatigue. His past medical history indicates he's suffering from anaemia for the past two (2) years. Family medical history indicates he lost his elder sister to acute leukemia. The physician has requested of an image to help inspect his blood flow, oxygen intake and metabolism of the organs and tissues. The patient is anxious because he remembers his sister suffered claustrophobia after the imaging. What education would you give to him to alleviate his fears about claustrophobia.
options: It is normal to experience that as it is associated with the process.
It is situational and short-lived and it would no longer bother him.
It is not everyone who experiences this condition after the procedure.
rationale: Claustrophobia is an anxiety disorder that is characterized by an irrational and intense fear of enclosed or small spaces. While some people may feel anxious or claustrophobic during imaging procedures, this is not a universal experience.

questionText: A 33-year-old Accountant who works in a community factory was seen trapped under debris after the building was razed down by fire. He sustained second degree burns with spinal injury. He is to be admitted into your ward for management. As a Registered Nurse who works at the burns unit, which of the following would you consider as the greatest threat to a patient with a major burns?
rationale: It can lead to decreased blood flow to vital organs and tissues, resulting in organ failure and death.

questionText: A 34 year old man has been brought in to the ward from theatre after an appendectomy. His BP has dropped from 140/80mmHg to 110/60mmHg with pulse change of 68bpm to 84bpm, which of the following would you include in your nursing action. I. Increase oxygen rate. II. Reduce IV infusion rate. III. Check vital signs IV. Assess for bleeding.
rationale: The patient's decreased BP and increased heart rate suggest hypovolemia and possible bleeding. Increasing the O2 rate can help ensure adequate tissue oxygenation, reducing the IV fusion rate can prevent fluid overload and assessing for beeding can help identify and address any post-operative haemorrhage.

questionText: A 34 year old woman has been diagnosed with an obstructed fallopian tube due to an infection, What will you anticipate teaching this patient about?
rationale: An obstructed fallopian tube can impair the passage of the egg for fertilization and implantation, making it difficult to get pregnant naturally.

questionText: A 34-year-old woman who is 24 weeks pregnant arrives at a level one trauma center after being struck by an all-terrain vehicle. She is stable at the seene with mild complaints of mid-epigastric pain on palpation. The nurse inmediately starts electronic fetal monitoring. Her respiratory rate is 16cpm, heart rate is 88 bpm, and a B/P of 130/85mmHg. Her CBC and urinalysis are normal and her toxicology sereen is negative. Trauma series radiographs are unremarkable. Kleihaur- Betke test is negative. Obstetrics has been consulted. Which of the following is the next best step in the evaluation of this patient?
options: Perform a speculum exam to look for signs of abruption.
Perform Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma examination at the bedside.
rationale: A FAST exam will provide real-time imaging of potential abdominal bleeding which needs to be ruled out given the traumatic injury.

questionText: A 35 year old Tiller has been referred to your facility with the diagnosis of spinal injury secondly to fall from height two days ago. On arrival to your ward, you noticed that patient was dehydrated and his clothes were soaked with urine. As a Registered Nurse, which of the following nursing interventions would you consider most appropriate for the management of patient's urinary related problem? I. Monitor patient's fluid intake and output. II. Insert the correct size of urinary catheter and connect to a drainage bag III. Check patient's vital signs and record. IV. Ensure patient has at least 31. of fluid omaks 24 hours.
rationale: Option iv focuses on increasing flou intake, which may exacerbate the patient's urmay incontinence,

questionText: A 35-year man with known ileocecal Crofur disease controlled with sulfasalazime presents w 1 week of severe pain and bright red bleeding afte bowel movements. The pain last about 45 minu and is improved with sitz baths. On examination you noticed a small superficial tear in the anodem in the posterior midline, without any othe abnormalities. He cannot tolerate anoscopy due pain. How do you proceed?
rationale: The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with an acute and fissure. Treatment options include stool softeners, increased fibre intake, sitz baths, and topical analgesics.

questionText: A 35-year-old trader reported to your facility will difficulty in swallowing, hoarseness of voice and pain in the neck and throat. Upon assessment, the lymph nodes in the neck were swollen with a lump A diagnosis of Thyroid Cancer was established Which of the following investigation is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
rationale: Biopsy is the gold standard for confirming a diagnosis of cancer. It involves taking a sample of the affected tissue for laborato analysis, which can accurately determine th presence of cancerous cells and the type of caticer

questionText: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for a bulge noted at the umbilicus by her primary physician, Other than morbid obesity, she denies any other medical history. On further questioning, the patient rates discomfort. The patient has a body mass index of 45 kg/m2 with a small bulge apparent at the umbilicus during Valsalva, with a fascial defect of approximately 5 mm. It is easily reducible. She has no previous scars. What do you recommend?
rationale: An ultrasound is a non-invasive and cost-effective modality that can diagnose an umbilical hernia, assess the size of the defect, and evaluate the contents of the hernia sac without radiation exposure.

questionText: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after an episode of syncope. Family members state that she developed acute-onset right-sided chest pain accompanied by shortness of breath earlier that day. She underwent an appendectomy approximately 1 month ago. Physical examination shows an heart rate of 120bpm, respiratory rate of 26cpm, and BP of 80/50mmHg. Computed tomographic pulmonary angiogram of the chest confirms the presence of large bilateral pulmonary emboli. Lower extremity ultrasound is negative for deep venous thrombosis. The patient is started on unfractionated heparin and transferred to the ICU, Four hours later, vital signs show a blood pressure of 70/50 mmHg and a heart rate of 125bpm. After appropriate fluid resuscitation, she is started on an infusion with norepinephrine. Which of the following is most appropriate at this time?
options: Continue anticoagulation and administer -PA only if an echocardiogram confirms RV straio,
Administer -PA and discontinue anticoagulation with heparin during thrombolysis.
Change anticoagulation to low-molecular-weight heparin and administer t-PA.
rationale: t-PA administration is reserved for high-risk patients with massive pulmonary embolism or significant RV strain, confirmed by echocardiography, and not routinely given in all patients with pulmonary embolism. Discontinuing anticoagulation during thrombolysis can increase the risk of recurrent thrombosis (B). Changing anticoagulation to low-molecular-weight heparin and administering t-PA simultaneously is not recommended because of the risk of bleeding complications. (C).

questionText: A 36 weeks pregnant mother reported to the OPD with contractions. The term "contraction of the uterus" means
options: Abdominal pain felt by the pregnant woman at term.
Temporary shortening and thickening of muscle fibres.
Permanent partial shortening of muscle fibres.
rationale: This occurs due to the coordinated contraction of uterine smooth musele cells, which is initiated by the release of oxytocin and leads to the expulsion of the foetus during childbirth,

questionText: A 36 year old mother of two is to undergo Hysterectomy as a result of bleeding fibroids. The main focus of psychological preparation of a patient for a surgical operation is
options: knowing the culture of the patient.
knowing what the patient knows about the operation.
knowing the supporting system of patient.
rationale: Patients may feel more confident and supported when they have a clear understanding of who will be there for them before, during, and after the surgery.

questionText: A 36-year-old teacher who has been on admission on your ward with a diagnosis of spinal injury is experiencing a sense of loss. She has been exhibiting signs of depression such as sadness and refusal to participate in self-care. As a Nurse, which of the following interventions would you avoid in the management of the patient's behavior? The nurse must I. Encourage family involvement in patient's care. II. Give cheerful and willing assistance with activities of daily living. III. Be sympathetic towards the patient. IV. Maintain a sense of humour.
rationale: Being sympathetic implies pity towards the patient which can make the patient feel helpless and incapable, while using humour can be misinterpreted as belittling the patient's feelings, especially when dealing with patients who are experiencing depression.

questionText: A 39-year-old Tiller reported to your facility with abdominal pain, straining on urination and urine dribbling out after urination. He further explained that he urinates frequently at night which affects his sleep. Upon assessment patient was diagnosed with Bemgn Prostatic Hyperplasia and admitted to the ward. As a nurse in charge, what actions would you take to reduce the risk of renal shut down? I. Monitor vital signs and report any abnormally. II. Weigh patient daily III. Maintain adequate intake and output. IV. Observe for peripheral edema.
rationale: Option I will help detect any early signs of renal shutdown. Il will help to monitor fluid status and detect any changes in weight. III will help prevent dehydration and ensure that the patient's kidneys are functioning optimally. IV is important to detect any fluid buildup, which may be a sign of renal failure.

questionText: A 37-year-old driver was involved in a Road Traffic Accident (RTA) and was diagnosed with head injury. He was transferred to your ward for further management. The patient has increased intracranial pressure and a decreased level of consciousness. There is the need to maintain a patent airway for this patient. As a Nurse, which nursing interventions would you carry out to achieve this goal? 1. Keep patient lying on the side. II. Elevate the head of the bed to 30 degrees. III. Suction patient less frequently a suction should last less than 10 seconds. IV. Insert nasogastric tube, aspirate stomach contents to prevent aspiration,
rationale: Keeping a patient with increased intracranial pressure lying on their side can increase the pressure on the affected side of the brain, leading to further damage and compromising the patient's neurological status.

questionText: A 37-year-old Exporter reported to the Out Patiem Department of your hospital with a history of blurred vision as a result of splash of pepper in the right eye. At the hospital, he was taken through series of visual test and examinations. A diagnosis of glaucoma was finally made. Which of the following would you include in your postoperative teaching for the client to avoid 1. Driving for long distance. II. Lifting objects. III.Bending.
rationale: These two activities can significantly increase intraocular pressure and put stress on the eye, which can interfere with the healing process and increase the risk of complications.

questionText: A 37-year-old female presents to her family physician with a complaint of nipple discharge that she noticed after awakening in the morning. According to the patient, the discharge was intermixed with a brown and clear substance without frank blood. She denies associated pain. fever, or tenderness. She takes a multivitamin and has no previous significant medical history. A physical examination reveals no palpable masses or cords. A small amount of brownish discharge is expressed with manual palpation of the nipple. Labs are unremarkable, and her beta-HCG is negative. Thyroid panel is within normal limits. She denies any trauma to the breast or recent infections. An ultrasound is completed and reveals a dilated duct in her left breast. She undergoes a bilateral mammogram which reveals a small focus of calcification within the duct. What is the next best step in management of this patient?
options: Punch biopsy of the skin, and percutaneous biopsy of any underlying lesion.
Aspiration then send fluid for gram stain and culture and start intravenous antibiotics.
Single duct excision is preferred because it breast-feed. preserves nipple sensation and the ability
rationale: This is the next best step becatise single duct excision is the gold standard for the diagnosis and treatment of intraductal papillomas which can present with nipple discharge and imaging findings like a dilated duct and calcifications.

questionText: A 37-year-old Mechanie with burns is to be admitted to your ward where you work. Upon assessment, you noticed that he has fluid filled vesicles that are red. shiny and moderate oedema on the face, anterior trunk, and in both arms and legs. He is also in severe pains suspected to be caused by nerve injury. The patient is at risk for wound infection related to
rationale: Burns disrupt the skin's natural barrier function, leaving it vulnerable to infection.

questionText: A 37-year-old woman was involved in a road traffic accident. She was rush to the emergency department with B/P of 70/30mmIIg, heart rate of 140/bpm, and O2 saturation of 72% She continues to decompensate despite two liters of iv fluids. Blood samples are drawn for type and cross match. What is the most appropriate treatment in this situation?
options: Transfuse type AB fresh frozen plasma to replace volume while waiting for type-specific.
Continue crystalloids and wait for the blood bank to release type-specific.
Transfuse type O negative blood first until patient's blood type is determined.
rationale: Type O negative blood can be given as it is considered a universal donor and does not require cross-matching.

questionText: A 38 year old Mechanic reported to your facility with lower abdominal pain, burning sensation during urination and a feeling of incomplete bladder emptying after urination for the past 3 weeks. Upon assessment he was diagnosed with urethral stricture and admitted to the surgical ward. As the nurse on duty, what nursing interventions would you take to promote urination? 1. Allow the patient to listen to sound of running water. II. Encourage regular intake of fluids if not contraindicated. III. Provide privacy. IV. Serve prescribed medication.
rationale: Option I can be a helpful distraction technique for patients who are having difficulty urinating. II helps to flush out the urinary system and reduce the risk of infection. III allows the patient to relax. IV may include medications such as alpha-blockers to help relax the urethru and improve urine flow,

questionText: A 38 year old Mechanic reported to your facility with lower abdominal pain, burning sensation during urination and a feeling of incomplete bladder emptying after urination for the past 3 weeks. Upon assessment he was diagnosed with urethral stricture and admitted to the surgical ward. As the nurse on duty, you have been instructed by the Nurse Manager to develop a nursing care plan for the client. You would include all the following in the patient's plan of care EXCEPT?
options: Keep patient in a supine position.
rationale: Urethral stricture is a condition that causes narrowing of the urethra, making it difficult to pass urine. Lying flat on their back (supine) can actually worsen the condition by putting pressure on the urethra and causing further obstruction of urine flow.

questionText: A 38-year-old woman reported to the reproductive health unit with the complains of faeces draining through the vagina. The gynaecologist assessed and suspected a
rationale: A rectovaginal fistula is a type of fistula that occurs between the rectum and the vagina, allowing for the passage of faecal matter or gas through the vagina.

questionText: A 3rd year midwifery student explained to her junior in the first year the hormone that is responsible for reduction of immune response in pregnancy. Which is the MOST appropriate answer?
rationale: During Pregnancy, progesterone levels increases substantially to prevent the mother's body from recognizing the foetus as foreign tissue and mounting an immunological attack against it.

questionText: A 40 year old man sustained an injury in the left palm while at work. He seeks for treatment at your unit with severe bleeding and happens to meet you. As the Charge Nurse, how would you stop the bleeding?
options: Sprinkle tablet salt on the wound to help stop bleeding.
Rinse the wound with water first.
Put clean absorbent bandages or fabric over the wound, keep applying pressure.
rationale: Applying pressure to the wound is the most effective way to stop bleeding as it promotes blood clotting and reduces blood flow to the injured aren.

questionText: A 40-year-old male is referred to a general surgeon for evaluation of an abdominal mass. The patient has a history of HIV infection which he acquired by having sex with other men. During physical examination, the surgeon palpates the abdominal mass, in addition to significant splenomegaly. A CT scan revealed lymphoma. An infectious disease panel is performed which is negative. Which of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis regarding this patient's abdominal mass?
rationale: Given the patient's HIV status which suppresses the immune system, he is prone to develop immunoblastic lymphoma. Marginal zone and follicular lymphomas are typically indolent, slow growing lymphomas which are less likely in an immunocompromised individual.

questionText: A 40-year-old male is referred to a general surgeon for evaluation of an abdominal mass. The patient has a history of HIV infection which he acquired by having sex with other men. During physical examination, the surgeon palpates an abdominal mass, in addition to significant splenomegaly. An infectious disease panel is performed which is negative. Which of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis regarding this patient's abdu mass?
rationale: It is the most common type lymphoma in patients with HIV infection and often associated with systemic sympton splenomegaly, and extranodal involvement

questionText: A 40-year-old woman sustained fracture of distal shaft of the femur. Which of the following commonly used in managing such fractures?
rationale: It is commonly used in managn fractures of the distal shaft of the femur due to ability to provide stable fixation, facilitate en mobilization, and promote bone healing.

questionText: A 41-year-old reported to the hospital with swelli on the head. Doctor assessed and suspecte meningioma, Which of the following is not a featu of meningioma?
rationale: Meningioma is a tumour that arises inn the meninges. It is generally slow growing an rarely metastasizes.

questionText: A 42-year old fashion designer has been admited the female surgical ward for removal of pant lump on the neck. The surgery was purposely improve patient quality of life. This type of surger will be termed;
rationale: It is a type of surgery aimed at relieve symptoms and improving quality of life, not cung the underlying condition. Reconstructive surgery aimed at restoring appearance or function, Curative surgery is aimed at curing the underl condition.

questionText: A 42-year-old Journalist reported to the Out Patient Department of your hospital with a history of blurred vision as a result of splash of pepper in the right eye At the hospital, he was taken through a series of visual test and examinations. A diagnosis of glaucoma was finally made. How would you interpret a visual acuity of $20/50?$ The patient
options: Cars sec at 20 feet instead of 50 feet
Can see 50 feet instead of 20 feet
rationale: A visual acuity of $20/50$ means that the patient can see at 20 feet what a person with normal vision can see at 50 feet.

questionText: A 43 year old interior decorator is booked to undergo laryngectomy. In patient teaching, what would be your priority?
options: Ability to sing and laugh would be lost.
Ensure adequate intake of soft foods.
Ability to and laugh would be maintained.
rationale: Laryngectomy removes the larynx. making eating and swallowing difficult; therefore, adequate nutrition and soft food intake are essential for a speedy recovery and health maintenance. while the ability to sing and laugh becomes secondary.

questionText: A 43 year old Tailor was involved in a road traffic accident and sustained fracture of the left femur with associated pain at the site. Which of the following best describe pain associated with the fracture?
rationale: Pain associated with bone fractures is asually described as sharp and piercing, as the sharp edges of the broken bone irritate and damage surrounding tissues and nerve endings.

questionText: A 43-year-old Mechanic with burns is to be admitted to your ward where you work. Upon assessment, you noticed that he has fluid filled vesieles that are red, shiny and moderate oedema on the face, anterior trunk, and in both arms and legs. He is also in severe pains suspected to be caused by nerve injury. Which of your following actions would be considered inappropriate in the management of the wound?
options: Cleaning of the wound daily with warm water.
Serving patient with high protein and caloric diet
Accurate recording of fluid intake and output.
rationale: It can cause further damage to the already fragile and sensitive tissue, as it may cause the blisters to rupture, increasing the risk of infection and delaying the healing process.

questionText: A 43-year-old miner was admitted with the diagnosis of spinal injury after he fell into a pit three days. As part of the initial management of the patient, surgery was not considered. The patient has been immobilized due to his condition. As a Nurse, you anticipated that he could develop bed sores. Which of the following nursing diagnoses would you formulate to guide your care for this patient?
options: Impaired skin integrity related to immobility.
Risk for impaired skin integrity related to immobility.
Risk for impaired skin integrity related to poor nutrition.
rationale: Because the patient has not yet developed skin breakdown, but is at risk due to the immobilization.

questionText: A 43-year-old reported to the health facility with a swelling on the right arm. Doctor assessed and suspected a tumour. Which of the following investigations confirms the doctors suspicion?
rationale: This is the only investigation that can provide a definitive diagnosis of a tumour, as it involves taking a sample of tissue from the suspected tumour site and examining it under a microscope to identify any abnormal or cancerous cells

questionText: A 44-year-old Accountant reported to the Out Patient Department of your hospital with a history of blurred vision as a result of splash of pepper in the right eye. At the hospital, he was taken through a series of visual test and examinations. A diagnosis of glaucoma was finally made. What should be the immediate nursing care for this patient?
rationale: Elevated pressure within the eye in glaucoma can cause damage to the optie nerve, leading to irreversible vision loss.

questionText: A 45 year old woman is admitted to the surgical emergency with complains of sudden onset of a sharp and severe pain at her left flank. Whiles awaiting the results from a CT scan, the Doctor plans to titrate a patient- controlled opioid infusion to relief her pain. During patient assessment you found out that this was her first time receiving opioid medication. Which of the following nursing action would be appropriate?
options: Teaching about the need to decrease opioid doses by the second day.
Assessing tor signs of that patient is becoming addicted to opioid.
Emphasizing that the risk of opioid side effect increases over time.
rationale: The patient is opioid-naive, increasing the risk of side effects. Educating the patient on potential adverse effects (nausea, drowsiness, constipation, and respiratory depression) allows for early identification and management, promoting safety and comfort.

questionText: A 45-year-old Driver started smoking at the age of 17 years. At age 34, he started experiencing some respiratory symptoms such as productive cough and occasionally difficulty in breathing. He was sent to the hospital and investigations revealed collection of fluids in the Right Lung. A diagnosis of Right Lung Abscess was established and the surgeon booked him for Pneumonectomy. When performing the recommended surgery of Pneumonectomy, what structure would be removed by the surgeon?
rationale: During a pneumonectomy, the entire lung is removed from the patient's thoracic cavity So in this case, the surgeon would remove the entire right lung of the patient.

questionText: A 45-year-old food vendor is to be admitted to your ward for further management of burns involving the face, anterior trunk, arms, perineum and both legs. She was unconscious on arrival as a result of hypoxia. Upon further observation, it was notaczaj that circulation to the patients lower extremities wa severely impaired. To prevent ischemi paraesthesia, necrosis and gangrene, which of the following procedures should the attending doctor perform?
rationale: It is a surgical procedure in which an incision is made through the eschar (dead tissue caused by a burn injury) to relieve pressure and restore circulation.

questionText: A 46-year-old miner was admitted with the diagnosis of spinal injury after he fell into a pit three days. After general ward rounds by a team of doctors, the patient has been booked for cervical traction. Patient appeared apprehensive. As a Nuse, what steps would you take to allay the fears of operation in the patient? 1. Allow the patient to ask questions to clear all his doubts. II. Introduce patient to a colleague nurse. III. Explain pain management strategies to be instituted after surgery. IV. Let the patient see the persons involved in his operation.
rationale: Option L. helps the patient gain a better understanding of the procedure and clarify any misconception about the surgery. III provides the patient with information about how pain will b managed post-surgery. TV help build trust and rapport between the patient and healthcare team.

questionText: A 48-year-old female patient undergoes open real of fractured femur which she sustained in a molur vehicle collision. Three days post-op, she devel a low grade fever, tachypnea, pleuritic, chest pain and a cough. CT scan reveals a pulmonary embolism. Which of the following findings MOST likely to be associated with this condition?
rationale: It indicates the presence of fibrin degradation products, which are produced when blood clots are broken down, and can be elevated in conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).

questionText: A 48-year-old Fisherman reported to your facility with the complaints of palpitation, hot flashes. excessive sweating and inability to tolerate heat. She also complained of change in body image with bulging eyes and weight loss. The doctor diagnosed his with Graves' Disease. Which of the following are possible side effects the patient is likely to experience after taking Methimazole? 1. Weight gain. II. Headache. III. Skin discoloration. IV. Hair loss.
rationale: Methimazole is an antithyroid medication that inhibits the synthesis of thyroid hormones in the body. Weight gain may be due to reduced metabolic rate, while headache and hair loss are attributed to allergic reactions to the drug. Skin discoloration is not a common side effect of Methimazole and is not typically associated with the drug.

questionText: A 49-year-old Accountant who works in a community factory was seen trapped under debris after the building was razed down by fire. He sustained second degree burns with spinal injury. He is to be admitted into your ward for management. In the fluid and electrolyte management of the patient, you would consider all the following as signs of fluid volume deficit EXCEPT
rationale: Rationale is not a sign of fluid volume deficit but rather a sign of decreased oxygenation or perfusion, while thirst and low urine output are classic signs of fluid volume deficit.

questionText: A 49-year-old man on your ward has been diagnosed as having an advanced form of Empyema, The best management for him would be
rationale: To drain the pus and fluid that has accumulated in the pleural space.

questionText: A 5 year old boy was brought to the Hospital with tympanic membrane perforation. He has been booked for surgery. Which of the following surgical procedure will the Doctor perform for the patient?
options: Ossiculoplasty Thes Cave perform to repair Smale bone
Blephonotomy-bis home to remove the excesive Skin Fron the eyelids
rationale: This surgical procedure is performed in cases of tympanic membrane perforation to relieve pressure, drain fluid or pus, and improve hearing.

questionText: A 50 year old patient weighing 96kg reported to the emergency ward with left hip pain following a minor trauma. He had fever and cough before the trauma. He was treated with ibuprofen for 7 days. He also presented with a limited and painful range of motion of the left hip and could not bear weight. Blood test showed raised WBC count. He was admitted for suspected osteomyelitis. What might have contributed to the patient developing osteomyelitis?
rationale: The patient's recent infection, combined with the use of corticosteroids which suppress the immune system, may have made the patient more vulnerable to developing osteomyelitis.

questionText: A 50-year-old carpenter sustained an injury to the back in an attempt of lifting a load at the workplace. At the casualty unit, he reported of severe backache with difficulty in movement. The following techniques must be observed when lifting load to prevent injury to the back EXCEPT
options: Flex the knee and hip joint before lifting.
Keep the object close to the body.
Bend the spine when lifting from the ground
rationale: It increases the distance between the load and the centre of gravity of the body, which can cause increased stress on the back and increase the risk of injury.

questionText: A 50-year-old female patient complains of morning stiffness in both her wrists and hands that improves gradually over the course of the day. She has recently felt unusually fatigued and complains of generalized aching. Which of the following diagnoses is MOST likely?
rationale: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the joints of the body. It is characterized by inflammation, pain, and stiffness that is often worse in the morning and improves throughout the day with activity.

questionText: A 52-year old man spilled hot coffee on a small portion of his thigh. The burn blisters is painful. The burn blanches on examination. Which of the following is the best treatment for the burn?
rationale: The burn blistered and blanched, indicating it is a superficial second-degree burn. Polysporon with Mepitel dressing is appropriate for superficial second-degree burns as it helps protect the burn, promote healing and provides pain relief.

questionText: A 54-year-old farmer reported to your facility with the complaints of palpitation, hot flashes, excessive sweating and inability to tolerate licat. She alse complains of change in body image with bulging eyes and weight loss. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient complaints
rationale: Is a type of autoimmune disorder that leads to overactivity of the thyroid gland, abe known as hyperthyroidism, causing symptoms such as palpitation, hot flashes, excessive sweating, weight loss, bulging eyes, and intolerance to heat due to increased metabolic activity.

questionText: A 55-year-old Mason reported to your facility with complaints of pain which radiates from the anal region to the scrotum. Upon assessment he was unable to void and was diagnosed with Renal Calculi. As the Nurse on duty, you are to provide education for the patient prior to discharge. Which of the following foods would you encourage client to avoid?
rationale: These foods are high in oxalate, a compound that binds with calcium in the urine, forming crystals that can lead to the formation of kidney stones.

questionText: A 55-year-old Ward Assistant reported to your facility with abdominal pain, straining on urination and urine dribbling out after urination. He furthur explained that he urinates frequently at night which affects his sleep. Upon assessment patient was diagnosed with Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) and admitted to the ward. A Radical Prostatectomy was performed on him. The patient has been transferred from the recovery to the surgical wand hours after surgery. As the Nurse on the shift, whit assessment data would you obtain: from patient? Check I. Vital signs. II. Urethral bleeding around catheter. III. Urine volume and colour.
rationale: These are crucial for detecting potential complications related to bleeding, infection, or urinary retention and guiding appropriate nursing interventions to promote the patient's recovery after Radical Prostatectomy (removal of the entire prostate gland along with the seminal vesicles) surgery.

questionText: A 58 year old lawyer on your ward has colostomy wound. The purpose of irrigating a colostomy is to
rationale: Irrigating a colostomy helps empty the bowel by flushing out its contents, which in turn regulates when and how often the stoma releases waste,

questionText: A 5-year-old girl presents with a recurrent UTI. Physical examination indicates possible sexual abuse. The child's mother is a single parent and lives with her boyfriend. She claimed she is "eertain" that the boyfriend has not sexually abused the child. She requests confidentiality and states she will not leave the child alone with the boyfriend. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate next step?
options: Without clear evidence of abuse, do not report this incident to authorities.
Report this case immediately to DOVVSU.
rationale: The mother's request for confidentiality should be respected, but it should not override the need to ensure the child's safety. Suspected child abuse must be reported to the authorities (e.g. DOVVSU - Domestic Violence and Victim Support Unit), and failure to do so could put the child at risk of further harm.

questionText: A 6 days post operative patient who had abdominal surgery is scheduled for discharge later today. On assessment before her discharge, you observed that the surgical wound site had about 2 inches of internal structures protruding through the incision. Which of the following interventions is appropriate?
options: Cover the wound with sterile normal saline dressing.
Put the patient in prone position to put pressure on the site.
Notify the doctor and administer prescribed anti emetic.
rationale: The patient is experiencing wound evisceration and the most immediate intervention is to protect the exposed tissue and prevent further damage or infection while you notify the Doctor.

questionText: A 60-year-old male patient complaints of a painless mass that protrudes from his anus when be defecates. It reduces spontaneously, but he sometimes sees bright red blood on the toilet paper and occasionally has a mucoid discharge from the anus that stains his underwear. Which of the following is this patient's MOST likely diagnosis?
rationale: The presence of a painless mass protruding from the anus, mucoid discharge and bright red blood on toilet paper is indicative of internal haemorrhoids rather than colon cancer, which typically presents with a change in bowel habits, weight loss, and anaemia.

questionText: A 60-year-old man presents to your office. He has been having bleeding per rectum for two months. His primary care physician diagnosed him with an external hemorrhoid in the left lateral position. On examination, you find a two and a half centimeter had mass located 3 centimeters outside the anal verge. It does not appear to be involving the sphincter mechanism on exam. Thera are no intra- anal abnormalities on a anoscopy. Biopsy performed reveals squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following is correct regarding the anatomy and likely treatment of this lesion?
options: This is a perianal squamous cell cancer that should be treated with chemoradiation.
This is a perianal squamous cell cancer thai should be treated with wide local exciston given its size.
This is a skin cancer and should be treated with wide local excision.
rationale: The described lesion is a perianal squamous cell carcinoma that can be treated with wide local excision to achieve complete removal of the tumour while preserving sphincter function.

questionText: A 63-year-old male with history of tobacco use, diabetes, and hypertension presents with severe symptoms of claudication. His left lower extremity is cool to touch, and his left big toe shows shinny skin, absent hair, and no palpabie dorsal pedis or posterior tibalis pulses. The arterial brachial index confirms peripheral arterial disease. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
rationale: The severity of his symptoms and the presence of peripheral arterial disease indicate that conservative measures such as exercise and smoking cessation are unlikely to be effective.

questionText: A 65-year-old woman with rectal prolapse comes to your facility with 6 months of increasing symptoms. She is a mother of three vaginal deliveries. She has become less social and isolated due to bowel incontinence. She denies urinary incontinence or constipation. You confirm reducible rectal prolapse on exam, about 10 em in length, with poor sphincter tone and no masses on digital exam. She has no evidence of cystocele or vaginal prolapse. She desires surgery. Which of the following should be done before proceeding with an operative repair?
rationale: It can confirm the extent of the rectal prolapse and to identify any associated pelvic organ prolapse, including a rectocele or cystocele, which could affeet the surgical approach.

questionText: A 67-year-old female patient who fell on an outstretched hand now complaints of hand pain. On examination, she has tenderness over the anatomic snuffbox. There is no evident of deformity and she has intact sensation and movement. What is the likely lesion?
rationale: The anatomic snuflbox overlies the scaphoid bone, which is commonly fractured in falls on outstretched hands. Tenderness over the snuffbox is a classic sign of this injury. The intact sensation and movement suggest that there is no nerve or tendon damage.

questionText: A 67-year-old High Court Judge reported to your facility with abdominal pain, straining on urination and urine dribbling out after urination. He further explained that he urinates frequently at night which affects his sleep. Upon assessment patient was diagnosed with Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) and admitted to the ward. Based on the assessment data obtained from the patient, which of the following statements are appropriate nursing diagnosis? 1. Urinary retention related to obstruction. II. Pain related to bladder distention. III. Anxiety related to inadequate knowledge of BPH. IV. Difficulty urinating related to pain
rationale: Option iv is not an appropriate nursing diagnosis because pain is not the cause of the difficulty urinating. The difficulty urinating is caused by the obstruction of the flow of urine due to the enlarged prostate.

questionText: A 68-year-old male on dialysis for end stage renal disease undergoes a kidney transplant without complication. Five weeks later he presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of not being able to urinate. His labs are remarkable for increased urine creatinine. The decision is made to perform a biopsy with results conclusive for acute rejection of the graft. The patient is placed on a rejection dosage of methylprednisolone. Two days later there is no change in status. He is then placed on a new immunosuppressive agent. He immediately develops lu like symptoms, tremors, and chest pain. What is the next course of management for this patient?
rationale: Plasmapheresis removes antibodies and plasma that may be rejecting the transplanted kidney.

questionText: A 69-year-old post-menopausal female complaints of leakage of urine with coughing and when she laughs. She states it has become increasingly worse over the past six months. Which of the under listed steps if taken by the Charge Nurse would be MOST beneficial to the patient?
options: Recommend fluid restriction to 1 litre per day.
Educate the patient about Kegel exercises
Refer the patient to a urologist for cystoscopy.
rationale: These types of exercises are beneficial for strengthening the pelvic floor muscles, which can help improve stress urinary incontinence caused by weakened muscles.

questionText: A 73-year-old Kente Weaver reported to your facility with abdominal pain, straining on urination and urine dribbling out after urination. He further explained that he urinates frequently at night which affects his sleep. Upon assessment patient was diagnosed with Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia and admitted to the ward. The patient is booked for Transurethral Resection of the Prostate. As a Nurse, what pre-operative nursing intervention would you take to reduce anxiety observed in the patient? 1. Reassure patient and family. 11. Give prescribed antibioties. III. Provide bowel preparation. IV. Provide information about the surgery.
rationale: Option I can help to reduce anxiety and fear of the unknown, while IV can also help to alleviate anxiety by giving the patient a better understanding of what to expect during and after the surgery.

questionText: A 75 year old man with a history of type 1 von Willebrand disease and an Hgb of 14.3 g/dL is scheduled for total hip replacement surgery. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment to decrease his risk of severe bleeding during his procedure?
rationale: Von Willebrand disease is a blende disorder caused by deficiem or defecuva Willebrand factor and factor VIII, and DDAVI (Desmopressin) can stimulate the release of vo Willebrand factor and factor VIII, which can hay reduce the risk of severe bleeding during surgery

questionText: A 75-year-old female with a past medical hatmy of well-controlled diabetes is adnuned to hospital with a right hip fracture. Her surgical repos is uncomplicated. Which of the following me can be taken post operatively to prevent delirune
options: Additional opioid pain uredication prior sedation wearing off
Giving lorazepam prophylactically to help wit sleep,
rationale: It prevents delirium by stimulating the mind and body, maintaming orientation circadian rhythins, and expediting recovery.

questionText: A 78-year-old Station Master reported to you facility with abdominal pain, straining on urinate and urine dribbling out after urination. He fut explained that he urinates frequently at night which affects his sleep. Upon assessment patient was diagnosed with Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia admitted to the ward. On the day of Surgery, ydi would be your immediate care before senim patient to the theatre? Help patient 1. Wear identification bracelet. II. Changed into hospital gown. III. Sign consent form.
rationale: Option 1. helps to identify the patte correctly and ensure that they receive the catre surgery. helps to prevent infection and previ access to the area that will be operated on, and l important to ensure that the patient understands the risks and benefits of the surgery has given their informed consent.

questionText: A 90 year old patient had a fall while going to the bathroom unassisted. It appears the patient has sustained fracture on the left leg and is unable to move the affected leg. Patient is oriented and alert but in severe pain, What would be your first nursing intervention?
options: Immobilize the fracture with a splint,
Elevate the extremity above the chest level.
Apply ice pack covered with towel to the site.
rationale: To stabilize the broken bone and prevent further injury or displacement and severe pain from movement until X-ray confirms the extent of injury and physician evaluates for definitive treatment.

questionText: A cylinder containing a gas can be identified by the colors. The oxygen cylinder body has a white neck with.. body.
rationale: The body of an oxygen cylinder is typically painted in blue colour to indicate that it contains compressed medical oxygen.

questionText: A decision of skin grafting was taken for a patient who sustained a burn injury. Which of the following skin grafts is least likely to be rejected by the patient's immune system?
rationale: Because the skin used for grafting is taken from the patient's own body. Allografts are taken from another person of the same species and may be rejected over time. Heterografts are taken from a different species and are often rejected quickly.

questionText: A diabetic patient who has undergone abdominal surgery has been observed to be experiencing wound evisceration. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate immediate nursing action to take? Cover the wound with
rationale: To keep the exposed organs moist. preventing tissue damage and reducing the risk of infection.

questionText: A Director in a Law Firm reported to the hospital with complains of bleeding haemorrhoids. He is shy and withdrawn. As a Nurse assessing this patient. what will be the possible cause of this condition?
rationale: His occupation suggests that he spends a significant amount of time sitting at a desk. Prolong sitting causes increased intra-abdominal pressure which gets transmitted to the lower rectum leading to engorgement of rectal veins resulting in haemorrhoids.

questionText: A farmer aged 55 years sustained a dislocation of the right arm while weeding on his farm. He reported at the emergency department with complains of pain in the right shoulder joint. The most serious complication of that can occur in this joint dislocation is
rationale: Due to lack of blood supply to the bone tissues surrounding the dislocated joint.

questionText: A female diabetic patient has been admitted to your ward for a laparotomy. What will you include in your nursing intervention to promote wound healing?
options: Ensure adequate amount of dietary carbohydrate.
Apply dry, sterile dressing to wound daily.
rationale: Hyperglycemia can impair the healing process by reducing blood flow to the wound site and impairing immune function.

questionText: A female patient scheduled for surgery is extremely obese and has cardiac problems. As a theater nurse you understand that placing this patient in a supine position will cause patient to experience
options: comfort without complications in that position.
limited range of motion when placed in that position.
orthopsea or dyspnoca when placed in that
rationale: It will cause orthopnoca or dyspnoca (difficulty breathing) due to reduced chest expansion and oxygen intake.

questionText: A housewife sustained a knife laceration while cooking. The wound bled profusely because the cut was deep and was rushed to the accident center for care. The wound was aseptically cleaned and sutured. She came back to the clinic after two weeks with much improvement. Her wound has healed by
rationale: Is a type of wound healing that occurs when the edges of a wound are brought together and held in place by sutures or staples.

questionText: A junior colleague of yours approached you to brief him on scrubbing before the commencement of operation at the theatre. As a final year student, your response may include the following EXCEPT;
options: Allow water from rinsed hands to drip from the elbow,
The hands should be raised above the elbow at all times after washing.
The second wash during the scrubbing should cover the whole length of the fore arm.
rationale: This can contaminate the sterile field, as the elbow is considered non-sterile during surgical hand scrubbing,

questionText: A long leg cert is applied for Kokui Kraba a 22-year-old man after sustaining fracture of the right tibia. The nurse observes that Kraba's exposed twes are swollen and he complained of numbness in the toe. Which of the following nursing diagnoses is most appropriate for kokui?
options: Fluid volume excess related to vascular compression by cast.
Peripheral dysfunction related to vascular insufficiency and nerve compression by cert
Fluid volume excess related to edema.
rationale: his swollen toes and indicative of impaired peripheral nerve function due to the constricting long leg cast.

questionText: A male patient aged 50 years as undergone a major surgical procedure and ban transferred to the recovery room where you wur further management. During your implinit operative assessment, you observed that pomem suddenly become cyanotic. The MOST app nursing action you will take will be to
options: administer oxygen through a nasal catimla 61pm.
reposition patient's head and determinar patency.
call for assistance and begin cardiopulm resuscitation.
rationale: Cyanosis indicates hypoxemia, md priority is to establish an open airway and en adequate oxygenation before initiating any funte interventions such as CPR.

questionText: A male patient aged 67 years dingnosed w benign prostate enlargement is expected to repo your facility for a prostatectomy. Laboratory and investigations have all been completed reviewed. Which of the following is the MOS appropriate pre-operative nursing care patient?
options: High oral fluid intake should be encouraged
Check for correct placement of urethral cathe
Maintain nil per os a day prior to surgery
rationale: To prevent the risk of aspirati stomach contents during anaesthesia.

questionText: A male patient presents with sudden a scrotal pain that radiates to his abdomen playing tennis, He denies sexual activity Be afebrile with normal vital signs. His left su tender and high-riding, and he has discharge or lesion. He has cremasterio refies affected side Which of the following treatment of choice?
options: Tlevation of the affected testes and erral
rationale: Rationale mmmintory

questionText: A male patient scheduled for surgery complains of increased respiratory secretions. Which of the anaesthetist? following drugs is likely to be administered by the
rationale: is an anticholinergic drug that reduces respiratory secretions by inhibiting parasympathetic stimulation.

questionText: A male patient started shivering uncontrollably after surgery. As part of your immediate post operative care, what nursing intervention would be your priority?
options: Apply warm blankets and continue oxygen therapy.
Consult the doctor for further orders.
Adjust the temperature in the room.
rationale: Shivering is a common response to anaesthesia and surgery, and it can increase oxygen consumption and heat loss. Therefore, the priority nursing intervention is to provide warmth and adequate oxygen as indicated in option A.

questionText: A man sustained a cut while gardening. Why would he be given anti-tetanus immunoglobulin?
options: To provide a target for lymphocytes
rationale: Tetanus can progress rapidly and be life- threatening, and the immunoglobulin contains pre- formed antibodies that can neutralize the tetanus unxin and provide immediate protection against the disease.

questionText: A manifestation of cancer of the cervix that would bring the patient to the gynaecologist is......
rationale: Cervical cancer causes changes in the cervix that can lead to bleeding, especially after the cervix is irritated during intercourse.

questionText: A medical procedure in which an olive-shape device is placed in the vaginal with the help of a laparoscopy in the treatment of vaginal hypoplasia is known as....
rationale: Is a surgical procedure used to treat vaginal agenesis or vaginal hypoplasia. In this procedure, an olive-shaped device is inserted laparoscopically into the space between the bladder and rectum and then pulled upwards over a period of several days.

questionText: A middle age man diagnosed of colon cancer uses opioid to control his pain at level 8 of 0-10 scale and request for something more potent. The BEST way to document this is......
rationale: Is a type of pain that occurs despite ongoing pain management with medication and is often more severe and sudden in onset than the baseline pain being managed. In this case, the patient is already using opioids to control their pain at a level of 8 out of 10, but is still experiencing pain severe enough to require additional medication.

questionText: A middle aged man who experienced a compound fracture of the right arm was rush to the emergency unit. What nursing intervention will you adopt with this type of fracture?
options: Cover the fracture with a sterile dressing
Place a tight compression bandage over the fracture.
Place the arm below the heart level.
rationale: To prevent contamination and reduce the risk of infection, as well as provide support and protection for the injured area..

questionText: A middle aged woman was admitted to the surgical unit on account of left sided hemiparesis, dizziness and severe headache. Which of the following nursing measures is inappropriate when providing oral hygiene?
options: Cleaning the mouth with a toothbrush and toothpaste.
Placing the patient on the back with pillow under the head.
rationale: It can increase intracranial pressure and exacerbate symptoms of dizziness and headache

questionText: A Midwife was teaching the student Nurse about the partograph and mentioned that the following are part of the progress of labour EXCEPT:
rationale: It refers to the shaping of the foetal head to fit through the maternal pelvis during labour and is not a measure of progress.

questionText: A newly married couple came to your facility and wanted to know when ovulation usually takes place so that, they can plan their family. In response the Midwife/Nurse explains that ovulation occurs 14
rationale: Ovulation usually occurs around day 14 of a 28-day menstrual cycle, which is 14 days before the start of the next menstrual period.

questionText: A Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory drugs commonly known as NSAIDs are classified under non-narcotic analgesics. Which of the following is widely used to manage post-operative pain?
rationale: It is an NSAID that has analgesic, anti- inflammatory, and antipyretic effects, making it effective in reducing pain and inflammation after surgery.

questionText: A normal reproductive function that way t altered in a patient who andergone prostatectomy is
options: Release of sperm from the epididyma
rationale: The prostate gland, which produces secretes seminal fluid. is removed durme procedure.

questionText: A nurse assessing a patient's ove identifies involuntary rhythmic movements of the eyes. Th can be documented as
rationale: It is a condition characterized by involuntary, repetitive, and rhythmic movemens the eyes, which may involve horizontal, vertical, rotary oscillations. It can be a normal physiologu response or a sign of an underlying neurological vestibular disorder.

questionText: A Nurse caring for a patient after a then surgery is concerned that the patient's midstem wound is at risk for dehiscence. Which of following is the BEST intervention to prevent complication?
options: Use appropriate sterile technique to change dressing
Place a pillow over incision site when chesti attempting to cough

rationale: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks through the nose or ears are signs of basilar skull fracture because they indicate a tear in the meninges, which are protective membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord, and this can cause CSF to leak out of the skull.

questionText: A patient on your ward had a successful abdominal surgery done and is recovering. As a nurse caring for this patient you would be most concerned about monitoring for wound dehiscence during which period.
rationale: Wound dehiscence (surgical incision separation) is more likely to occur on the 2nd to 3rd postoperative day because this is the time when the surgical incision is most vulnerable due to decreased tensile strength, leading to increased stress on the wound from coughing, vomiting, and other activities.

questionText: A patient on your ward is experiencing a Hypovolemic shock on your ward following a burn injury can be prevented through 1. Administering IV fluids II. Administering oxygen III. Putting patient in semi fowlers position IV. Giving patient analgesies

III can help to increase venons return and improve cardiac output, thereby preventing shock. Giving patient analgesics can help to manage pain but does not directly prevent hypovolemic shock.

questionText: A patient post operative day three (3) is unable to move his bowel. As a newly qualified nurse you know that difficulty in having bowel movement days after surgery can result from 1. Decreased mobility II. Inadequate oral intake III. Opioid analgesics IV. High fatty diet
rationale: Decreased mobility leads to decreased bowel motility, Opioid analgesics results in decreased stool bulk and slower intestinal transit time, while opioid analgesics decrease bowel motility. High fatty diet does not directly affect bowel motility or stool consistency.

questionText: A patient presents with shallow ulcerated lesions on the lower legs above ankles. questionText: A patient presents with wrist drop. The Charge Nurse would be concerned about compression of which of the following nerves?

questionText: A patient who is undergoing thyroidectoon requires constant monitoring. Which of the theate team members is primarily responsible monitoring patient's physical status throughout surgery?
rationale: The anaesthetist directly monitors the patient's physiological status by checking parameters such as pulse, blood pressure, oxygen levels, temperature etc. to ensure adequate depth of anaesthesia and physiological stability.

questionText: A patient who receives general anaesthesia passes through several stages. In which of the stages can the surgical procedure be performed?

rationale: Chest tube insertion is done to remove air (pneumothorax) and/or blood (hemothorax) from the pleural space to prevent respiratory distress and maintain lung function.

questionText: A patient who undergues surgery to remove tumours in the hypothalamus or pituitary gland are likely to suffer

questionText: A patient who was diagnosed with Hyperthyroidism was recently discharged from your facility. She was put on Carbimazole. questionText: A patient with a traumatic wound necessitated debridement of 4 cm of devitalized tissue. Which of the following is the MOST appropriate wound care treatment?
